text.value: Let the projectile be launched with an initial velocity v_0 which can be expressed as the sum of horizontal and vertical components as follows:

content.alt: v sub zero equals v sub zero sub x i plus v sub zero sub y j

text.value: The components x_{0_x} and v_{0_y} can be found if the initial launch angle, \theta, is known:

data.alt: v sub 0 sub x equals v sub 0 times cosine of theta
v sub 0 sub t equals v sub 0 times sine of theta

text.value: See also the section Parabolic equation for information on finding the initial velocity.

In projectile motion, the horizontal motion and the vertical motion are independent of each other; that is, neither motion affects the other. This is the principle of compound motion established by Galileo in 1638.
Image with width and height - not recommended as image will not respect aspect ratio (width="400" height="100"):
No size or width or height results in images at their native size:
Native size images are still restricted to the width of the page (at native size this image would be 1080x720 pixels)
This question is a pick-one-multiple-correct type question with feedback and an included solution:
Here you could provide a long-form solution which would provide a detailed answer to the question.
You can also include a button that would link back to the page containing more relevant information. In this example this button will take you back to page 1:
Which equation describes horizontal displacement of projectile motion?

content.alt: x equals v sub x times t
x equals v sub i x times t plus one half a sub x times t squared

text.value: Correct, however horizontal acceleration is zero so you can simplify this equation into the form below:

content.alt: x equals v sub x times t
x equals one half a sub x times t squared

text.value: The a_x term representing horizontal acceleration is always 0 so this equation is simply x = 0.

IFrames display external sites within Obojobo.
This is a webpage type IFrame with default attributes that make it suitable to embed webpages. webpage type Iframes will load and display their content when View Content is selected.
This is a media type IFrame with default attributes. Since it is optimized for media playback, its defaults differ from the webpage defaults.
Use the media type when embedding video or interactive material. Otherwise, use the webpage type when embedding websites. If no type is specified, media will be used.
The autoload property allows an IFrame to load automatically. Autoloading is not recommended, as it may affect the load speed of the Obojobo Module.

The IFrame below omits the title property. When omitted, the embedded URL is shown instead. In general, it is recommended to include a title, as this is more readable than a URL (and will also be read aloud by screen-readers).
A custom width and height can be provided, as shown below. This IFrame also has no border (once it is loaded).

The fit property controls an IFrame's behavior when constricted by the available space. The IFrame below specifies fit="scale", which means it will scale down proportionally as the IFrame box shrinks. To see it in action, view the IFrame content, then try reducing the size of the browser until the IFrame can no longer fit in the available space - the inner contents will decrease in size. This is the default setting when type is set to media (and in general is recommended when embedding media).

The other fit type is fit="scroll". This does not scale down the inner contents. The contents remain the same size while the IFrame box that contains them becomes skinnier. If the external content won't fit inside the reduced IFrame box, the user will need to scroll inside the IFrame to see all of the content. This is the default setting when type is set to webpage (and in general is recommended when embedding content with text).

The initialZoom property allows an IFrame to be set to a custom zoom level. In the example below, the embedded webpage is zoomed to 150% of its original size. This can be used to tailor embedded content to more closely match the text size of the Obojobo module (or if the embedded content defaults to a small size).
An IFrame can contain any of the three control types: reload, new-window and zoom.

The IFrame below has only the reload control. reload allows the user to refresh the site within the IFrame. It's helpful if the user manages to navigate to another page inside the IFrame - The reload button will restore the original embedded page.
The IFrame below has only the new-window control. new-window allows the user to load the external site in a new tab or a new window (depending on browser defaults).
The IFrame below has only the zoom controls. Zoom enables the user to adjust the iframe scale.
Finally, in the example below, all of the controls have been removed:

If the controls property is not specified, the defaults will be used. With media type IFrames, the default controls include reload only. For webpage type IFrames, all controls (reload, new-window and zoom) are enabled by default.
Math equations can be specified with LaTeX:

content.alt: x equals negative b plus or minus the square root of b squared minus 4 a c, end square root, all over 2 a

text.value: Using the label option you can label your equation:

content.alt: delta x equals the integral from t 0 to t 1 of v of t, d t

text.value: You can also include math inline with other text, such as \alpha = \omega t.

In general HTML usage is not recommended since Obojobo cannot easily parse or understand HTML content and text selection is not accurate. However HTML allows you to do things which are not possible with standard Obojobo components.

content.label: Click me to see a message

value.title: I have a message for you:

text.value: Button using a text group rather than a label:
Click me to jump to page 1!
Bold, Italic, Superscript2, Subscript2, Links, Strikethrough content, a quotation, monospaced text and in-line math equations: \frac{dy}{dx}
This is an ordered list however the second indent-level is unordered (using square) bullets and the forth indent level is using uppercase letters starting at the 10th letter (J)

Unlike HTML whitespace is retained for element content. Note the tab characters at the start and end of this text as well as the extra lines above and below. See the XML source to view the whitespace for this element.
